awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Interpreters and Scientists Working On Our Parks
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative resources for use in a variety of settings.  This project aims to enhance the National Parks System in the U.S. by engaging the system as a resource for science education. The advantage of using national parks for science education is that they are natural settings with dynamic changes and offering countless avenues for citizen inquiry.   The project will build collaborations between park-based scientists whose work happens out of the public eye and interpreters who are visible to millions of annual visitors.  Based on pilot studies done at Carlsbad Caverns National Park, the researchers will extend this work in six national parks with different characteristics. Partners in this endeavor include Winston-Salem State University, and TERC, Inc. 

This project's goal is to establish  a model for how national parks can be resources for science education and learning. The project will concentrate on the that is being done in six national parks, by scientists who are generally from academic institutions. The scientists have selected each park for research because of its unique features, for example, Carlsbad Caverns' unique feature is its bat population. The main methodology of this proposed effort is to translate these research endeavors and results from the scientists to the park visitors in such ways as to make the process enjoyable, informative, and thought-provoking. Evaluation elements will be included every step in this process in order to not only determine if learning has occurred but also how effectively the science has been translated.

por.por_cntn:
The Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative approaches to STEM learning in a variety of settings.  National parks are a destination for millions of people every year. These natural settings host hundreds of research and monitoring projects designed to answer foundational questions about how our world works. The project fostered collaborations between park-based scientists, whose work largely happens away from the public, and interpreters, who interact with millions of visitors annually.

 Intellectual Merit. iSWOOP developed a model for showcasing science underway at national parks. iSWOOP coordinated the development and delivery of digital libraries including animations, still photos, thermal and high-speed videos, and maps to give visual support to explanations of particular scientific studies. Early career filmmakers and students worked at the intersection of art and science to create stunning and provocative imagery. In the hands of park interpreters visualizations were a jumping off point for observations, predictions, and speculation during interactions with park visitors. After iSWOOP brought scientists and park rangers into direct contact during multi-session professional development workshops, park leaders observed use of more interactive methods for engaging visitors, the creation of new science-focused programs, and greater public interest in science.

As a result of iSWOOP, 83% (31 of 37 interpreters surveyed) indicated that their understanding of scientific research taking place at their park had changed. iSWOOP both increased their awareness of the research being conducted in their parks and led to a deeper understanding of the research featured. Park leaders observed positive changes in park programming and visitor experiences that resulted from iSWOOP, such as the creation of new science-focused programs, more interactive methods for engaging visitors, and greater public interest in science. Park rangers explained that they were sharing stories about specific researchers and their methods. They told visitors stories of near failures and innovative solutions to reinforce the idea that science is a process. More than half showed visualizations as a way to invite visitors to generate questions and begin to answer their own questions. A majority was including research questions and findings from featured scientists to explore how we know what we know.

Broader Impacts. Tens of thousands of members of the public took part in conversations about natural resources and conservation efforts. They discussed research approaches that scientists and resource managers might take to answer pressing questions and gained an appreciation for science conducted in parks, outside of academic, hospital, and private labs. Featured scientists, including early- or mid-career women pursuing studies in botany, paleoecology, and geology, adopted similar inquiry-based approaches in talks and in their classrooms. First generation undergraduate students assisted with research and data visualizations.  

The Park Service has increased attention to science communication and sought to increase collaborations for this purpose among scientists with active research and its interpretation and education staff.

Project leaders from TERC in Cambridge, MA, Winston-Salem State University, along with colleagues from other universities and the National Park Service, have published research findings and insights and made presentations to scientists, interpreters, and audiences of environmental educators. Resources are available online for no cost.
